review_title: An amazing chance to get some hands-on experience with students and review older material

pros: The bulk of the work can be done on one's own time. The in-lab work is relaxed and involves redirecting students in the appropriate direction mostly.
cons: The minimum wage of Ohio is nothing to boast about. For the work done, the pay was fair.

job_title: Visiting Assistant Professor in Oberlin, OH
pros: Wonderful, engaging students. Great, talented and caring colleagues.
cons: Pay, location (unless you really love tiny town life, which some do)

pros: The city of Oberlin is very quaint and nice. The students are exceptionally fun to work with and are very inspiring!
cons: There is very low morale at Oberlin College. I left 2 years ago and everyone I was close with has either left the college within the last 2 years or is in the midst of leaving. The pay at the College has a lot of discrepancies and there is evidence that men are paid significantly lower than women. The culture is pretty miserable and everyone feels jaded by the slashing of retirement and benefits, the low salaries, the evening and weekend hours, and the lack of general honest appreciation from the college. Oberlin unfortunately rests on its laurels from the amazing work it did decades ago and has since been lost to the old ways of operating.

pros: This job entails teaching, doing research, mentoring students, and helping to run a college. These are all intrinsically rewarding things.
cons: Structural forces. There are simply too many people interested in a professor job, so there's no incentive for colleges to take the needs of their professors as workers seriously. Demographic shifts mean that the future of higher ed for most small liberal arts colleges is pretty bleak. Some of these institutions have large endowments, which makes it seem like they should be able to support the people doing the actual work of teaching and research. In fact, they use this money to attract and retain students, not faculty. As a result, morale becomes quite bad among faculty and the ones who have marketable skills leave. The faculty who can't or won't leave get bitter and stop contributing. Vicious cycle.

pros: Had fun working with students
cons: Not really any, nothing bad

job_title: Visiting Assistant Professor in Oberlin, OH
pros: great students, supportive colleagues. cost of living is cheap in area.
cons: Living in Oberlin is like being at work all the time. No division of work/life. Expectation of being parental figure to students. Institution is in austerity period, cutting benefits. Little employee support

review_title: Great Students, Diminishing Compensation and Democratic Governance
job_title: Visiting Assistant Professor in Oberlin, OH
pros: Oberlin students are wonderful: engaging, creative, and always open to new ideas. A joy to teach.
cons: The College has implemented cuts to faculty compensation and benefits that make us among the most uncompetitive in our peer group. Faculty governance has been eroded and staff unions busted by a Board of Trustees and administration focused more on implementing corporate governance strategies than honor Oberlin's history of social justice.

review_title: A revolving door for good talent
job_title: Assistant Director of Annual Giving in Oberlin, OH
pros: Decent health and retirement benefits, friendly staff, cute campus.

review_title: Think twice before accepting a job there
job_title: Administrative Secretary II in Oberlin, OH
pros: Money and health care is good.
cons: Management does whatever they want and ignores union contracts. Many jobs have been cut the past couple of years. In return, burden put upon those still there with no extra compensation, just much added stress. Too much backstabbing and gossip among the staff. All the added stress made things worse than ever. Don't ever think anyone is your friend. Use your own judgement, don't listen to anyone else. Keep to yourself, you're better off.

pros: Everyone here is great. Work here!

review_title: Very good place to work, although town has drawbacks
pros: You get to work with very talented students, and you have highly accomplished colleagues who are always willing to talk or give advice. The classrooms have state-of-the-art technology, and for such a small town, they attract world-class performers and lecturers.
cons: The course load for the professors is heavy, while they also have high research expectations. In a typical semester, I teach 4 classes (2 sections of 2 courses each), or 5 (4 sections of a 2-credit course, and 1 upper-division course). Because it is so small, the town of Oberlin can feel isolating to people who are not involved in the college. The College currently faces financial challenges (nothing dire, but which will require making some difficult choices), and people are uncertain how salary and benefits will be affected.

pros: The professors and department workers are in general very friendly, accommodating, people. I worked there while I was a student, for two different labs, and both were very positive experiences. It's also LGBTQA friendly.
cons: Oberlin is, of course, in the middle of nowhere. There's not much to do. If you don't have friends within Oberlin, the chances of feeling stranded and bored are high. In terms of lab jobs, the career opportunities are low (unless you're on track to be a professor/assistant professor/etc).

review_title: A good start for international students
pros: If you are an international student, it is quite easy to instantly find a job on campus and the international student office will guide you to fill in the necessary forms for applying SSN. They will arrange a bus to drive to that office and after several weeks you could get your SSN.
cons: For academic positions, it pays significantly less than working with CDS. Teaching assistant only pays you $7.95 per hour, while after a semester, you will be promoted to a slightly higher salary of $8.1 per hour. However, working in CDS such as line runner will give you $8.7 per hour, and even more for washing dishes.

pros: Passionate and inspiring students helped to give value to work contribution. Good benefits and vacation time.
cons: Oberlin College is in deep need of a cultural change. Oberlin has a low trust culture and is deeply siloed, which make it hard to partner on cross-departmental initiatives. The top-down hierarchy makes it really hard to keep people accountable when they are practicing poor behaviors and people are treated as if they are dispensable.

review_title: Great resources and students; declining campus culture
pros: Phenomenal art museum, terrific library and staff, brilliant and unique students, flexibility in teaching. Proximity to Cleveland, a surprisingly great city. Commitment to LGBT rights, environmental activism, diverse campus.
cons: Insular, more invested in progressive politics than in first-rate academics. Oberlin hire too many of their own alumni and in general there is a feeling of entrenchment among faculty. Tremendous racial tension on campus. Things are also going downhill due to infighting, poor management of resources, and poor leadership, including an Arts & Sciences Dean who has connected the school to some shady for-profit education outfits. Still an excellent place in many ways--high quality of education in the classroom--but in other ways the outlook is not very sunny at this time (late 2016).

job_title: Tour Guide, Campus Visit Assistant in Oberlin, OH
pros: I worked as a Tour Guide for Oberlin College Office of Admissions.  It was a really fun job, especially for an extrovert like me.  I loved talking to parents and kids about Oberlin and showing them around.  The tours are only an hour, so you can easily fit this job into your schedule.
cons: You have to talk constantly for about an hour.  I don't think there really are any cons.  The only problem would be that sometimes it can be very cold, raining, or very hot.

review_title: Typical college annual fund, both the good and the bad
pros: Immediate supervisors are quite willing to try new approaches if a good argument can be made. Benefits are great, salary fine for the low cost of living in town.
cons: Single and in your 20s/30s - live in Cleveland instead. Interactions with other offices are a major mixed bag -  some people, including managers, should have been fired years ago.

review_title: CDS - Great for Oberlin Students and Adults with college bound kids.
pros:
- Inexpensive College Town
- Free Meals (depending on position)
- Great benefits (tuition assistance for children)
- Friendly clients
cons:
- Sometimes dealing with unmotivated co-workers (mainly the temps)
- management can be shaky at times
- prone to disorder
- lack of incentive to perform well

job_title: Guest Services Assistant in Oberlin, OH
pros: Friendly work environment and a genuine engagement in making sure workers understood what they were doing and how best to help with problems around the office. Frequent attempts to keep job morale high translated to fun and office cameraderie between the student staff and the managers.
cons: Low hourly rate and sometimes condescending behavior from management because so many of their employees were students that were always in rotation. Was offered job perks like overtime that never came to fruition.

pros: The admin asst work-week is less than forty hours a week so work-life balance is quite strong and the hiring process was straightforward
cons: There was no room for growth in terms of moving from a unionized admin assistant position to an administrative and professional staff position, but otherwise it was great

review_title: Best you can get if you want a small-town, liberal college
pros: The students were wonderful, work was flexible, was given a lot of responsibility for an entry-level position. Lots to do for such a small town.
cons: Isolated (the town is fantastic and friendly if you like the small-town atmosphere--but NOT the place for you if you crave a city, or if you're single). It would not be good for networking if higher education is not your long-term goal.

pros:
best salary for a student job
very autonomous
sometimes great coworkers
getting favors from resed
adrian is excellent
cons:
extremely underpaid compared to RAs at other schools
many RDs (direct boss) don't want to work there, and can make your life unpleasant

review_title: Facilities manager of hourly workers ranging from skilled trades to custodial.
pros: Great institution for higher learning. Great people to network with. Management and workers have a good relationship at times. But even during difficult high times, eeveryone comes together to make the campus run.
cons: There are some issues with trust between the union and upper management. Seems as if things were dealt with in the open, things would run smoother.

pros: Great professors provide constant guidance, but allow for some independent direction as well.  Excellent learning opportunity.  Apply for this job if you are an Oberlin student interested in Science.
cons: Oberlin feels a little lonely in the summer sometimes, but all of the other researchers are in the same boat so you make new friends.

job_title: Circulation Desk Assistant in Oberlin, OH
pros: I enjoyed working there for many reasons: active and successful subbing system, great quiet atmosphere, beautiful building with tall windows, friendly employers, and wonderful students.
cons: I have few complaints. I could not necessarily get all the hours that I wanted - but no job is perfect.

review_title: Oberlin College does not care about their employees, just saving money.
